comments.commentBody: Not beside the point at all, but actually the whole point.  This has been going on for many years, as have other terrible problems that the aboriginal peoples of Canada have endured for many years.  There are many parallels between their treatment and that of our Native America population.  And it's disgraceful.

Sorry, "media" outlets like Gawker NEED some chilling effect. Ironic how many people wouldn't see a problem with what Gawker does until they are the target.

Hogan's sex tape was not ever a legitimate target for public dissemination. Period. They violated his rights and they're going to suffer as a result. What comes around goes around. Thiel is absolutely right that Gawker is in a category by itself.

Always puzzling how people so adept at one thing (starting companies) can be so terrible at other things, such as not being evil tyrants. This "I'm only targetting Gawker" defense is garbage. Any dim-wit can see plainly that cases like this will have a chilling effect on the media. Mr. Thiel is a threat to the country, what a shocker that he's also a Trump dead-ender.

Yes, "everything in America is about money"
That's why the American Empire is declining.

Actually, on TV adverts, there are lending companies who claim they will finance personal injury trial cases. Been a lot of stories about this.

http://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/25/magazine/should-you-be-allowed-to-inve...
If everything in America were not about money, what would it be about? Right and wrong? Oh, please, give me a few days to stop laughing.

I am not worried about this specific case as I am about "litigation financing." This is just one more thing in American life that is being commoditized. Like health care and education. Does everything is America have to be about money, ultimately? Just like in health care and education, the privileged few will have the ability to fight injustice whereas those without the means (or backers, more precisely) will suffer the injustice.

It's common in investigations to talk first to the underlings, to box in the higher-ups. Clinton said she'd cooperate if and when the FBI asks her to. But notice that the article says she (and her aides) refused to be interviewed by the Inspector General.

In other words, Hillary SAYS she'll cooperate, but she doesn't. She talks the talk but doesn't walk the walk.

Strangle "public discourse"? A Hulk Hogan sex tape is public discourse? He's barely a celebrity any more. It's no more public discourse than a sex tape of your own.

Denton deserved the judgment. Let's not forget his own editor claimed in his testimony the only celebrity sex tape he would not consider newsworthy would be one involving a child under 4 years old.

That Thiel served as a sort of "legal defense fund" didn't change the facts of the case.

You don't like Thiel because he's smart and he prefers Trump to Hillary. I would suggest those two things correlate strongly. But for you, that means it's time to trot out once again your threadbare Nazi comparisons.
Since when is somebody's sex life public discourse?  Gawker ridicules and humiliates people for no other reason than lurid entertainment value.  What goes around comes around.

You must be joking. Gawker used content that was STOLEN.

No big deal, the simple-minded say?

Wrong. Before Maria Shriver's medical records were STOLEN, the paps STEALING medical records was near-epidemic.

http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-ucla-medical-data-20150717-story.html

Finally, a law was passed, a few went to jail, and that finally slowed. Still, the market for STOLEN medical records is high -- like $50/file. Sick, disgusting, and vile.

Gawker got what was coming to them. Get over it.

I have little use for Gawker, but a great deal less for a plutocrat who attempts clandestinely to strangle public discourse, however distasteful. It does not surprise me that he supports the Trump candidacy, since that worthy has already announced that he intends to bring the press (the Times has been specifically mentioned) to heel. "When they came for Gawker Media I said nothing, because I was not an internet gossipmonger..."
Super news, Mac!

I was in mid-Reply to Mac here when I accidentally hit something and the Comments went Poof! I'll reconstruct, and apologize in advance if I inadvertently posted part of this post already.

I join in the cheers for your good news, Mac. I'm especially glad your pain level is dropping, both because it's a sign the chemo is working and because less pain means better quality of life.

Hand up for WOOL before LOAM. I was starting this segment without any lead-ins because just following my nose was leading me into cut-off areas. But the only [Skating maneuver] I could think of beginning with a W is a wally, and it didn't fit. So I looked at the downs and saw APP and that I had been misdirected into the wrong nursery. (I didn't actually know that LOAM is sold by the bagful, since I know it only from XWPs. It could be sold by the box- or truckful for all I know.)

No surprise you didn't catch on to that, MacKnight, since apparently none of us is willing to leave you a LOAM.

Still Li'l Leapy

ONION RING gave me the theme, although thinking of rocket o-rings still nearly brings me to tears. Sad day.

I found the puzzle easy after getting the theme. The M of MCS was my last entry. I had wool before LOAM. I'm still not sure what nursery rhyme references LOAM. Maybe someone can enlighten me.

Good news on the cancer front. My immune system recovered quickly, so I start round 2 of the Cytoxin on June 1. My pain level is dropping slowly, which is a sign my chemo is working. All good news; yay.

Charlotte is no better, We gave the Panthers $95 million for improvements to their stadium and then they said we couldn't hire more police. They also stopped picking up trash at apartments so now we all have to pay an extra $8 to subsidize the low rent district's trash pick up.
My water bill this month.
Water $10.40
Sewage use $18. 60
Sewage fee $11;50
Water fee $6.50
Storm water runoff $ $32.

The fees on the water are six times higher than the water.
I can think of one parallel.

Hi from the other Saratoga. We were actually named for the NY Saratoga, trying to sell itself as a spa center, the "Saratoga of California." Another city, in the wine country, tried the same thing but we got there first. They had to settle for "Calistoga."

I like the original Saratoga. It has seasons. Winter's set up beats ours (if you like winter).

Hdb I'm going to have no choice but to support Hillary if the alternative is Trump, but don't assume that democrats are lock-step in denial of this error or mistake or intentional flouting of State department rules.  I'll criticize her for this until the cows come home, but I've never expected flawless politicians, including those whose motives are unblemished.  This is not excusable but she can learn from it.  Fortunately, it appears there was no successful security breach but even if there were, it would pale in comparison to serious security breaches such as Aldrich Ames and the mishandled Edward Lee Howard.  To repeat:  no excuses offered to her.  But she is light-years ahead of Trump as presidential timber.
Needless to say, Mrs.Clinton is to politics what Mr. Trump is to real estate, similarly manipulatively powerful. I doubt anyone, at least within her party, would confront her if she is elected.

Because pictures you take of yourself and may show to your friends are not public domain. They are very personally and professionally damaging, certainly in the case of Hulk Hogan.

Gawker is trash.

It could mean that guy on the right, but let us hope that people come to their senses and realize that Hillary is a better choice than the counter choice.  I just hope she can truly be honest.  Again, that's been an issue for her.
The article said permission was required, and she never asked for it and it was never given
And as another commenter has said here, she was more protective of the privacy of her Wall Street speeches than she was of national security documents.  Bad Hillary.

@JHM.
Is that really what Brian Fallon said, word for word? That is so awkwardly put that I don't know what he meant. Wait a minute. The reports suggested an anti-Clinton bias in the inspector general's office and the inspector was appointed by Obama? So Hillary's people are saying that Obama's appointee is biased?

What happened to Clinton's stance of being so loyal and defensive of the man who defeated her during her first run? Practically morphing into a replica of him for a run in the Oval Office? Good grief.

5-25-16@11:38 pm

The harm is in her office's attempt to evade the requirements of the relevant open-records statutes.

If members of her inner circle get indicted, will you remain so blasé? Didn't think so.

RTW, all salaried employees understand that if they use personal email for business use, they will quickly be reprimanded and failing to correct future similar usage, they will be fired. Why did Clinton think that it was "okay" to use a personal email account? This isn't about CS degrees and IT dept. This is about personal responsibility and Clinton failed that test. This is another example of rules not applying to people high up while ordinary folks are beat up for the slightest of infractions.

You make a very good point. It was widely reported that President Obama had a propensity to use a smart phone when he was first elected.  However, he was advised against that and restrained.  Why wasn't Sec. Clinton similiarly advised?   Maybe a setup to undermine her?    I think it will become clear in the coming days that the screwup was not on the part of Sec Clinton, but on the State Department Inspector General whose principal job it is to protect her from scandal.   For the misinformed, that is what Inspector Generals in every Government Agency, Federal, State and Local,  are charged with.   Time to investigate them for dereliction of duty!

You haven't read the report.

Repeated efforts to stop her were quashed by higher ups, who were told legal clearance had been given when it hadn't, and then made it clear to never bring up the subject again.

It's hard to cry foul when your boss is the one who decides whether or not you can cry -- or come back to your job the next day.

It's not the machines that will kill us, at least not of their own volition. That level of AI is still a long way off.

It is the Elite who own and control the machines that will kill us. (See for example, http://www.newsweek.com/robot-security-guard-anbot-robotics-452934) This technology, once invented, cannot be uninvented. The most plausible scenarios do not see a happy ending for most people.

It has been said before, but it bears repeating . . . and repeating. Stripped of its ephemera, human history up until the industrial era was a story of psychopaths competing (sometimes collaborating) to attain power, then using that power to dominate and brutalise their fellow human beings. Such Rulers felt no remorse in wasting the lives of "their" Subjects.

If that behaviour seemed to moderate in the Modern Era it was not because human psychology had evolved. It was just that the nature of the industrial economy - the need to train large numbers of Subjects to operate the complex but not fully automated machinery - made it expedient, for a time, for the Elite to offer certain concessions to those Subjects.

But those conditions were anomalous . . . and temporary. With the onset of AI and robotics such concessions are no longer needed.

What we have witnessed in the past 30 years is the steady restoration of the historic norm, the "refeudalisation" of society.

And the system of "elective" government (it was never Democracy) is an utterly inadequate defence against it.

and Elke

Martin- thanks for locating Victoria on Vancouver Island; a ferry ride away from Vancouver on the Mainland. Saves me a lecture. Am waiting for a pop-up ad from that TAPAS BAR to show up on my screen. They don't take reservations- must be good....

The NYT did a series of stories a few years ago about a young girl in a large African American family living in a Brooklyn homeless shelter. The story got tons of attention and had the pictures you are thinking of.

And now the Clinton apologists are trying to blame the State Department for not stopping her?  The evidence is overwhelming that she was warned, that she lied about the server, that she lied about what was on it, that she lied about what she deleted, that she lied to Congress, that she destroyed subpoenaed evidence and that she continues to lie.  Hillary Clinton belongs in jail and if she isn't imprisoned, we owe Assande, Snowden, Guccifer, Petraeus and Scooter Libby pardons and a ticker tape parade.

She is not going to win.  And don't blame Bernie's supporters; she is her own worst enemy.  Her arrogance is her downfall, as it nearly was with Bill.  He managed to survive in large part because Hillary stood by him.  They are a sorry pair.
